measured_by: boundary separation parameter of the starting-time Drift Diffusion Model (stDDM)
justification: The article states that “older adults showed higher boundary separation (i.e. response caution) …”, indicating that the boundary-separation estimate in the stDDM is used to quantify the construct of response caution.

measured_by: drift rate parameter of the starting-time Drift Diffusion Model (stDDM)
justification: The paper links drift rate to how quickly evidence is accumulated, noting predictions that “older adults would show slower drift rates (i.e., smaller weighting strength parameters in the stDDM), potentially indicating age-related increases in the noise of neural information processing.”

measured_by: non-decision time parameter of the starting-time Drift Diffusion Model (stDDM)
justification: It reports that “older adults had longer non-decision times …”, showing that the non-decision-time parameter of the stDDM serves as the measure for pre- and post-decision processes that are not part of evidence accumulation.

measured_by: probability weight parameter of the starting-time Drift Diffusion Model (stDDM)
justification: The Results section says, “Both age groups placed more weight on probability than magnitude information,” and the parameter labelled ‘Probability Weight’ in the stDDM quantifies this construct.

The Methods describe that participants performed “a mixed lottery choice task … [which] constituted the EVs … of value-based decision-making,” indicating the task is the behavioural instrument used to measure value-based risky decision-making.
